[4579, 1, 'Oh yeah, to answer your other question from earlier, my definition of art is anything created. This is a different definition from "arts". The arts with an s include skills that are honed and passed down from master to student but might not have anything to do with creation.\nA work of art (without an s) must be a work--something created. Food can be art, but isn\'t always. So art must be intentional.\n\nArt can be bad subjectively, of course. The one who made it might deem it bad--a poor example of their craft. The beholder of the art might deem it bad, saying it doesn\'t give them any valuable feeling or doesn\'t suit their aesthetic.\n\nCan it be objectively bad? Maybe... I\'d define "bad" in this context as "providing no value". Value could be pleasure, emotion, meaning, or to fulfill a purpose. Bad art is art that no one gains any value from. It\'d be hard to prove it\'s truly bad because "one man\'s trash is another man\'s treasure."', 'https://discord.com/channels/657566118285672469/804066380328599572/1114165065424306307']

[11222, 1, "When talking about creating government programs that help people, I often hear those two arguments:\n\n1. We can't give everyone free help, because some people I don't think deserve free help will get the free help.\n\n2. But how could we possibly afford to give people x help?\n\nFor the 1st point. If we're talking just about the things Joe listed (Shelter, food, water, electricity, Healthcare, education, child care), then I think you should have these as rights. I couldn't care less if some people take advantage of them, because it would raise the quality of life for everybody. Besides, we as a country already over-produce most consumer products. Every year craploads of brand new cars get dumped in landfills when they go unsold, more houses/dwellings sit empty than there are homeless people, there is so much food waste. We've also made leaps and bounds in terms of automation. We see robots and software taking jobs as a bad thing, but only because we don't have these universal rights. We could all stand to work a little less and have a little more.\n\nFor point 2, we‚Äôre the United States of America. We have enough wealth/economic power to put rocket boosters on Hawaii, launch it into the sun, and build a stronger and faster Hawaii in its place. The fact that most of that economic power is in the hands of a few corporations is something that can be fixed with policy. Taxes on the wealthy have been dropping every decade since WWII. I don‚Äôt have the perfect economic prescription for what percentages of what should be taxed. I‚Äôm just saying the wealth is there, and it could be utilized much better for the good of everyone.\n\nThe other thing to consider is we can look to Europe and see good implementations of pretty much everything Joe mentioned in one country or another. The main thing holding us back isn't a lack of resources or some people living off of government benefits. It's the majority of our economic resources being held, unused by the 1%.", 'https://discord.com/channels/657566118285672469/804066380328599572/941448926677053451']

[13057, 1, 'The law / chaos dichotomy in D&D is fairly well set and understood by the community as "does this character follow a code (law) or do they make choices that appear to bring them closer to their goal at the moment" with neutral being largely understood to mean "some of both". So, the average person: They generally agree that some kind of code is good but pretty consistently break the code and have a rational for doing so. 50/50, neutral. \n\nThe good evil dichotomy is a much more caustic discussion. The core gameplay loop is about memorization of paths and sequences through the process of trial and error. [3270, 2, "All of the talk of ability aside. I philosophically disagree with the need to add increased or decreased difficulty to games. [3288, 2, 'Souls games arnt about reaction time, they‚Äôre rhythm games. You‚Äôre memorizing *when* to press the dodge button, it‚Äôs not about how fast can the player react. Most boss moves are highly telegraphed and are designed so that after you get familiar with their moves you can see them well in advance. I personally believe anyone can beat a souls game with enough practice. Obviously different people will learn at different rates, and previous souls game experience effects that. but in my personal experience I‚Äôve watched multiple people who where objectively trash at souls games become better throughout their first play through, when they finally finish and decide to restart, the game is easy because they‚Äôve already memorized the timings for all the bosses. My first run through of ds3 took like 70 hours, which is NOT short. My second run through took 10 hours, and my third took 5. I have completed that game 7 times now and it poses no challenge, but with elden ring I‚Äôm still on my first play through. Everything is new and I‚Äôm getting shit on. That‚Äôs just the way the game goes.\n\nElden ring also really increases the accessibility for new comers to the franchise imo because if you get stuck on a boss you can just explore in a different direction for awhile, and acquire a bunch of items and levels. You might find that when you come back to the boss you were stuck on that the new weapons you found or all the extra levels you got made the boss just that little bit easier to finally beat them.\n\nAnd worse come to worse, all souls games have multiplayer so if you have a friend who is willing, you can team up for harder bosses. And even though the boss gets a huge health boost for each additional player, being able to switch the bosses Agro can take the pressure off long enough for even the most fragile characters to survive that little bit longer to defeat the boss.\n\n\n\nFighting games genuinely do have that problem because reaction time is way more important when you‚Äôre fighting a human player, who is unpredictable, and often the moves are much much faster.\nSo I absolutely agree that anyone who has a bad reaction time will probably enjoy the game less.\n\nBut yeah contrary to popular belief dark souls is in fact not the definition of bad game design, it‚Äôs just a guitar hero wearing the skin of Skyrim', 'https://discord.com/channels/657566118285672469/804066380328599572/1166110439793504418']

[7249, 2, "> Anyways, hot take, accessibility and immersiveness are directly related. If one game is unplayable to a person bc of disability and one isn‚Äôt, then the first game can‚Äôt possibly be more immersive.\n<@200816606656331776> \n\nIt can be more immersive (for its audience) while being less inclusive of a larger audience. Immersion and inclusiveness aren't co-dependent.\n\nEDIT: I will agree that games with larger audiences are generally better than games with smaller audiences. Inclusiveness is good for games, but not necessary. Super Meat Boy is a great example. It was designed to be the hardest 2D platformer to date. Many people can't play hard 2D platformers. But that doesn't effect the quality of the game. \n\nOfc, you were talking about immersion, not quality. My immersion example is VR gaming. It doesn't get any more immersive than that. However, I can't play VR games. I get really bad headaches from them. Many have motion controls too, so they aren't at all inclusive, despite being incredibly immersive.", 'https://discord.com/channels/657566118285672469/804066380328599572/1031018555778543747']

[7426, 2, "This goes back to the argument I bring up a lot about love not being deserved. Just like no one deserves love, no one deserves forgiveness. Acceptance /tolerance, in this case, is about letting people keep doing what they're doing and potentially even being complicit in the behavior.\n\nForgiveness is simply allowing yourself to let go of that person/behavior/situation. To not allow yourself to be fueled by resentment over it. It's impossible to even deal with a lot of situations until after you've forgiven the people involved because you can't see it objectively until you do. If someone has hurt you and you've forgiven them. [7430, 2, 'You apologize for mistakes and for transgressions. One is moral culpability. The other is practical culpability. I guess it depends on the context to determine which is which. If the "mistake" was you doing something stupid when you should have known better, being lazy, giving into temptation, then it was not actually a mistake even if some want to characterize it as such. It was something you could have and should have controlled.\n\nOn the other hand, if it was truly a mistake or a failure of skill, that has no moral culpability. [7673, 2, 'Back to what <@163108529689853953> said... I hate to agree with notable hater and troll, Luke... buuuuut.... Yeah the middle ground is the place to be most of the time. You have to converse with them, and they cannot leave or harm you. How do you interact with them? Crusts answer was to punch the racist in the face (fair lol). My approach was one of "I want to understand why you think the way that you do". My goal is never to agree with my enemy, or bolster my friends simply because I agree or don\'t agree, but approach every interaction as best I can from a testing and weighing of what they are saying and then understand *why* they are saying it. 9/10 I\'ve found that by simply quietly listening without agreeing, you can find where they actually get their ideas from. [8068, 2, 'I have mixed feelings on this. (but also for context idk how Genshin\'s specific monetization works) I agree that it\'s infantilizing to just say people have no self control. And it should be an obvious fact that every game with monetization (which is almost all of them now, because it works well for making money) will try to psychologically guide people to spend more.\nBut there\'s definitely a line that can be crossed where a game (or other business) is super predatory in how they try to incentivize you to give them money. Payday and title loans are super fucking predatory on people who don\'t have much money, and I wish they were illegal. Even though their customers are voluntarily participating in it, they\'re so misled and forced to overpay that it\'s just not a fair system. I don\'t agree with a hyperlibertarian stance that would say "well, you signed it, so it\'s 100% your fault and the company has no part in being shitty here".\nIf a large number of people are maxing out credit cards to play a game, it\'s a good sign that the game has crossed that line between decent monetization and tricking people into paying you too much. On the other hand, a few people who can afford it paying a lot, or the occasional person with an overspending problem going overboard, doesn\'t necessarily show predatory behavior IMO. Some other things in life also have a line that is sometimes crossed, like gambling. They toe a fine line between things like putting gambling problem help lines out there, and making gambling more addictive, and not taking credit cards for payment because it encourages overspending/debt, and not advertising to minors or allowing them to play as they\'re especially vulnerable. I don\'t know all the ins and outs of it, but I\'m sure there are some regulations around that that don\'t exist around games and their monetization.', 'https://discord.com/channels/657566118285672469/804066380328599572/1012431024862539929']

[8136, 2, 'I\'d agree that it\'s generally true that an author\'s work will reflect their personal beliefs and convictions, but to say that it\'s impossible to separate the writer from the writing feels like a bit of a stretch. [10494, 2, 'I personally view Skyrim as more genre-defining for open world than BotW and Elden Ring as it heralded the trend to make as many big games as possible after it also open world.\n\nThat said, BotW added new elements to the genre such as an interactive environment. Being able to set things on fire based on their material and having items interact with each other in unique ways broke new ground for the genre.\n\nElden Ring removed an unnecessary feature that had been included in many open world games previously to create a more pure open world experience. Namely, a quest tracker/log. Some "open world" games still have linear stories and  encourage you to follow certain rails. [12696, 2, 'While I love the concept of the "Cube Rule" of food identification, I have a few major issues with the terms chosen by the OP.\n\n1) While quiche is all well and good, this category would serve the culinary world much better by calling that shape a pie. A quiche is just an egg pie. You can have a fruit pie, meat pie, dessert pie, etc. Pies can have a thin layer on top without them converting to the category I will complain about next.\n\n2) Instead of calzone, which is really just a pizza (toast) folded over onto itself, we should call this either ravioli or a dumpling. Dumplings are more widely recognized and used in many more cultures; however, some people might argue that a dumpling with no filling (e.g. gnocchi) should not count for this category. To such people, I point to toast, which does not require any topping to be toast.\n\n3) This is my most grievous complaint. Only about a third of sushi has the shape OP labeled as sushi. Makizushi is a type of sushi made by rolling ingredients with a seaweed wrapper, but it\'s neither the most common nor the most famous type of sushi. It\'s just the one commonly used to convince people to try sushi for the first time (i.e. California Rolls). Nigiri is the most common and popular type of sushi. Nigiri is toast. The category labeled "sushi" by the OP should instead, I propose and insist, be called burrito. Makizushi is just a sushi burrito that\'s been cut into slices. Same goes for pinwheel sandwiches. Can we say that the art can compare to Van Gogh? Can the Musical score stand anywhere near a Mozart composition? Can the story hold up next to the works of Shakespeare? [5231, 3, "The problem is definitely what you call boycott culture. Boycott's, like strikes, only work when a high enough percentage of the population participates. [7804, 3, "I have a few points where I do or don't agree with you.. \n1. They definitely thought they were Christians (correct me if I'm wrong), and I think saying now they weren't is just a no true Scotsman fallacy. You can have issue with their previous beliefs or how they represent that now, but being a Christian itself is, in my opinion, absolutely a self-assigned label that will invariably include people/beliefs you don't like.\n\n2. Every Christian's interpretation of the Bible is heavily influenced by the culture that tells them how to interpret the Bible. You may think that your interpretation is better, but faith leaders in their tradition think theirs is. I don't see how either of you can show you're objectively more correct.\n\n3. Saying that deconstruction *has to* result in the same outcome as what theirs did is clearly false, I agree with you there. To give them the benefit of the doubt, it may be that they didn't see any other choice once they started asking the questions. It's true to some large extent that you don't choose your beliefs, I can't *choose* to actually believe something for five minutes just to prove it to myself. I could imagine it's true or act like it's true, and eventually that may likely convince me it's true, but I cannot consciously decide my beliefs. This meant that liberal ideas of economic competition had to be replaced by the subjection of the economy to the dictates of the national interest. Similarly, any ‚Äúsocialist‚Äù ideas in the Nazi programme had to follow the same dictates. Hitler was never a socialist. [7683, 6, 'Middle grounds are great for opinions, preferences, and disagreements on procedures.\n\nMiddle grounds don\'t exist for facts. When things are stated as simple facts, it\'s not possible to have a middle ground. This is the biggest problem with Facebook/Twitter arguments. It often starts with something stated as a fact and another person saying providing direct opposition yet claiming that opposite to instead be fact.\n\nIf you are willing to compromise, you must not state your stance as a fact. If you\'re not willing to compromise, you\'re (probably) wasting everyone\'s time by talking about it.\n\nI\'m always(?) a middle ground kind of person when it\'s possible and reasonable. When something\'s presented as a hard fact, I can\'t easily agree to it if I know the wording isn\'t completely true.\n\n"All cops are bad." This is presented as a simple fact. I can\'t agree. I know very good people who are cops and who are appalled when they see cops from other precincts abuse their power. Not all groups of police are corrupt. Most? Probably. Definitely not all.\n\nIf you instead explain your stance, "All cops who stand by as their system and officers in it abuse their power are bad whether they actively participate or not..." Now I agree with you! Absolutely!\n\n"People who voted Trump are all racists/sexists/ect." This isn\'t true. Some are simple brainwashed. Others are trapped because of family and circumstance.
